objectives.description: Recognize the importance of researching charitable organizations before donating money, time, or resources.
Assess the transparency and financial health of nonprofit organizations using available tools and resources.
Use the PACED decision-making model to compare and select charitable organizations to support.
Recognize red flags and warning signs of ineffective or potentially fraudulent charitable organizations.

leftPanel.title: Not All Charities Are Equal
paragraphs: Charitable giving is powerful, but not all organizations use donations with the same efficiency or effectiveness.
Some may allocate large portions of funds to administrative costs rather than direct programs.
Others might not be legitimate at allâ€”charity scams cost Americans hundreds of millions of dollars each year.

leftPanel.title: Key Metrics to Review
paragraphs: Program Expense Ratio: What % of funds goes directly to programs vs. overhead? (70%+ is generally good)
Fundraising Efficiency: How much does it cost to raise $1? (Under $0.25 is efficient)
Working Capital: Does the organization have enough resources to sustain operations?
Executive Compensation: Are leadership salaries reasonable for the organization's size?

stats.label: Scam Tactic: Pressure for Immediate Donations in {{STATE_NAME}}

leftPanel.title: Maria's PACED Analysis
paragraphs: Maria has $500 to donate for environmental conservation. She researched two organizations using evaluation tools:
EcoAction: 82% to programs, local focus, 15 years operating, strong financial health, limited outcome data
Green Planet Alliance: 75% to programs, global policy focus, 8 years, detailed impact reports, rapid growth
Using PACED, Maria decided EcoAction better aligned with her valuesâ€”she prefers supporting local efforts with lower overhead.

leftPanel.title: John Identifies a Scam
paragraphs: John received a call from "Children's Cancer Relief Fund" pressuring him for an immediate credit card donation with a "matching gift deadline."
